meanings.definition: Relating to or denoting a process by which two photographs of the same object taken at slightly different angles are viewed together, creating an impression of depth and solidity.
meanings.sent1: The stereoscopic images made the movie look more real.
meanings.sent2: The new TV had a stereoscopic feature that made the pictures pop.
meanings.sent3: The stereoscopic glasses made everything seem closer than it really was.
meanings.sent4: Her mind was a stereoscopic view of memories, each one distinct and vivid.
meanings.sent5: The artist used a stereoscopic effect to bring the painting to life.

meanings.definition: Of or relating to a stereoscope or stereoscopy.
meanings.sent1: The old stereoscopic viewer was a fascinating antique.
meanings.sent2: The museum displayed various stereoscopic devices from different eras.
meanings.sent3: He tried to take a stereoscopic selfie with the vintage viewer.
meanings.sent4: Her eyes felt like a stereoscopic lens, capturing every detail around her.
meanings.sent5: The room was filled with the nostalgic charm of stereoscopic gadgets.

meanings.definition: Capable of or relating to three-dimensional vision.
meanings.sent1: His stereoscopic vision allowed him to judge distances accurately.
meanings.sent2: The animal's stereoscopic sight helped it catch its prey easily.
meanings.sent3: She joked that her cat had stereoscopic eyes for spotting treats.
meanings.sent4: The city skyline appeared stereoscopic against the setting sun.
meanings.sent5: The VR headset provided a truly stereoscopic experience of the virtual world.
